subject: Re: [junit] can anyone help me to resolve my problem,
msgSnippet: ... I applaud the fact that you want to do it this way, but you would have to control the equals() method to be able to use assertEquals(). Since you don t
messageBody:
Rajesh K wrote:
> can anyone help me to resolve my problem,
>
> acually i m having one method which returns org.jdom.Document object.
>
> i want to check whether the returned object having the value what we
> expecting
>
> i tried like
>
> assertEquals(org.jdom.Document expected, returning object)
>
> but the object having different memory location, so that we can't test
> like this.
>
> then how? plzzzzzzzzz

I applaud the fact that you want to do it this way, but you would have
to control the equals() method to be able to use assertEquals(). Since
you don't control the equals() method for Document objects, you need to
do something different.

One option is to create a class that wraps Document and provides the
corresponding equals() method:

class DocumentValueObject...
private Document document;

// constructor taking a Document as a parameter

public boolean equals(Object other) {
// compare Document contents node by node...
}
}

Now you could do this:

assertEquals(new DocumentValueObject(expected), new
DocumentValueObject(returningObject));

I'm not aware of anyone who has written a general-purpose, reusable
equals() method for Document objects. You could be the first!

Good luck.
--
J. B. (Joe) Rainsberger
Diaspar Software Services
http://www.diasparsoftware.com
2005 Gordon Pask Award Winner for contribution to Agile practice
Author, JUnit Recipes: Practical Methods for Programmer Testing
